Winfrey chose Vuong's latest book, "The Emperor of Gladness," to be the 114th pick for her book club, and she filmed the moment she called him to tell him the news.
"Is this Ocean?" Winfrey asked in a video posted on TikTok on May 14.
"Yes, Anne?" Vuong replied, to which Winfrey said, "No, this is not Anne. This is Oprah. How are ya?"
Vuong, completely surprised, asked, "What?"
"This is Oprah Winfrey! How are you?" she responded.
Vuong was shocked into absolute silence for several seconds, leading Oprah to say, "Hello?"
The footage then cuts to Vuong saying, "Oh my God, are you kidding?"
Oprah replied, "No, I'm not kidding you one bit. I'm calling you because, Ocean, I love 'The Emperor of Gladness' so much, and I am so excited to choose it for the Oprah's Book Club!"
Vuong couldn't believe it, and then shared why the selection was such an honor to him personally.
"You don't understand how much this means to me," Vuong said. "Your voice was on the background of my entire childhood."
Vuong shared that he helped answer the phone at his mother's nail salon as a child, and that Winfrey's show would frequently be playing on the TV.
"Your voice and your show is the only thing that she values," Vuong said.
Vuong's mother died in 2019. He told Winfrey what his mother would have thought about her choice for her book club.
"Pulitzer, Nobel, all that be damned, but if she was alive today..." he said, before Winfrey replied and said that it meant to much to her to hear that.

"I'm so proud that you recognized the love and humanity in the book because that's the love and humanity your career and your show has given us," Vuong said. "You give so many people hope and your voice is literally in our consciousness as we work and try to strive together a life."
Vuong, the author of bestselling novel "On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous," shared more about Winfrey's impact on his life in an interview on CBS Mornings on May 13.

"It's such an honor to have her pick the book, because, you know, where I come from, working class people, the act of reading can be very intimidating," he said. "Most of the clients in my mother's nail salon were working women, single mothers who didn't have second degrees, who only have high school educations."
"And when I watched them, when they saw her book club show, they get up from the chair with a different posture," he added.
Vuong said he would watch them get up and say, "I'm going to walk across this strip mall, I'm going to go to Barnes and Noble and get that book."

"She made the act of reading accessible, and I watched these women feel so empowered, and I think it opened up the possibility of reading for them in ways that they never would have gotten," he said. "And as a little boy, I didn't know I was going to be a writer, but I think I saw that first."

"I said, 'I don't know what that is — books — but they can change the posture of somebody's mother so that they can stand a little taller and walk across and get a book with that kind of confidence,' because she gave them a ticket into the discourse," he continued. "And that access means so much to me, especially as a first generation immigrant, as a first generation (person) to go to college, as an educator, it does the world."

title: Cassie Ventura after testifying in Diddy case: ‘The more I remember, the more I will never forget’
summary: Cassie Ventura issued a defiant statement after closed-door testimony in connection with the federal investigation into allegations of abuse, trafficking and racketeering involving record executive and rapper Sean “Diddy” Combs.
story: Cassie Ventura issued a defiant statement following a week of closed-door testimony in connection with the federal investigation into allegations of abuse, trafficking and racketeering involving record executive and rapper Sean “Diddy” Combs. Her former partner is accused of subjecting her to years of sexual violence and abuse.
Outside the Manhattan courthouse, Ventura's attorney Douglas Wigdor read statements on behalf of the 38-year-old singer and her husband, according to Associated Press.
"I hope that my testimony has given strength and a voice to other survivors, and can help others who have suffered to speak up and also heal from the abuse and fear," her statement reads in part.

In 2023, Ventura filed a lawsuit against Combs wherein she accused him of subjecting her to a decade of rape and physical abuse and control. While the suit was settled just one day after it was filed, the aftermath of her claims prompted a watershed of similar allegations from other women and drew attention from federal authorities, leading to a larger criminal investigation.
Combs has pleaded not guilty to all charges and remains in custody.
Read on for the statements issued by Ventura and her husband, actor Alex Fine, per Associated Press.
Cassie Ventura's statement

“This week has been extremely challenging, but also remarkably empowering and healing for me. I hope that my testimony has given strength and a voice to other survivors, and can help others who have suffered to speak up and also heal from the abuse and fear.

"For me, the more I heal, the more I can remember. And the more I can remember, the more I will never forget. I want to thank my family and my advocates for their unwavering support, and I’m grateful for all the kindness and encouragement that I have received.
"I’m glad to put this chapter of my life to rest. As I turn to focus on the conclusion of my pregnancy, I ask for privacy for me and for my growing family.”
Statement from Alex Fine
“Over the past five days, the world has gotten to witness the strength and bravery of my wife freeing herself of her past.

“I have felt so many things sitting there. I have felt tremendous pride and overwhelming love for Cass. I have felt profound anger that she has been subjected to sitting in front of a person who tried to break her. So to him and all of those who helped him along the way, please know this: You did not. You did not break her spirit, nor her smile, that lights up every room. You did not break the souls of a mother who gives the best hugs and plays the silliest games with our little girls. You did not break the woman who has made me a better man.”
“Cassie saved Cassie. She alone broke free from abuse, coercion, violence and threats. She did the work of fighting the demons that only a demon himself could have done to her.”

title: Is ‘Saturday Night Live’ new tonight? About the May 17 episode
summary: Is ‘Saturday Night Live’ new tonight? All about the Season 50 finale, airing May 17.
story: "Saturday Night Live" is wrapping up its 50th season on May 17.
The comedy show's milestone season has been filled with fun since it kicked off in September 2024 with host Jean Smart and musical guest Jelly Roll.

A-list stars continued to swing by Studio 8H to host the show, including John Mulaney, Jack Black, Timothée Chalamet, Ariana Grande, Walton Goggins, Dave Chappelle, Mikey Madison, Martin Short, Quinta Brunson, Lady Gaga and Charli XCX.
Musical guests this season have included Elton John, who performed with Brandi Carlile, Lizzo, Gracie Abrams, Stevie Nicks, Billie Eilish, Arcade Fire, Chappell Roan, Morgan Wallen and Benson Boone.
Which brings us to this week...
Is there a new episode of ‘SNL’ tonight?
Yes indeed! On May 17, "SNL" will cap off Season 50 by bringing back Scarlett Johansson to host the show for the seventh time.
The May 17 episode marks the Season 50 finale.

Johansson first hosted way back in January 2006. Though she last hosted "SNL" in December 2019, she’s made several appearances on the show since then, including as recently as April 2025 when she revived her Ivanka Trump impression for a controversial “White Lotus” parody that spoofed the Trump administration.
The “Jurassic World Rebirth” star, who is married to “SNL” writer and “Weekend Update” star Colin Jost, will be joined by musical guest Bad Bunny, making his third appearance on the show.

This week, Johansson appeared in a string of zany promos for the show, including one "Jurassic"-style sketch that showed Johansson running in horror after husband Jost pitches a sketch where the two finally kiss.
Luckily, cast member — and Jost's nemesis — Sarah Sherman was on hand to make sure that smooch would never happen.

title: Blake Shelton, Annie Murphy, Rob Lowe and oh-so much more behind the scenes at TODAY
summary: TODAY.com spoke with some of the guests on the TODAY show this week, including Rob Lowe, Jim Gaffigan, Blake Shelton, Annie Murphy and more.
story: In Greenroom Confidential, reporters and editors at TODAY.com share a look at what actors, authors, performers and more guests told us behind the scenes at TODAY. A variety of old and new friends dropped by Studio 1A, including Rob Lowe, Jim Gaffigan, Annie Murphy and reigning men's figure skating world champ Ilia Malinin. Find out what you missed!
Rob Lowe talks about lessons no one wants to learn

Rob Lowe visited Studio 1A on Monday to talk about his podcast, “Literally!”, as well as his beloved grandmother, Mim, who passed away from breast cancer and the clinical trials he believes helped prolong her life.
Later, Lowe sat down with TODAY.com to answer a burning question on everyone’s mind: Will there be a sequel to the 1985 movie “St. Elmo’s Fire”?
“There’s a script due any minute,” Lowe said. “And hopefully it will be good, and we’ll go off and make it.”
He also revealed which of the cast members were interested in returning and, apparently, it looks like all of them are on board.
“Everybody wants to do it,” he told TODAY.com.
Lowe also took a few minutes to chat about the plot of his upcoming horror film, “The Third Parent,” which will be released later this year.
“It’s very, very creepy. It’s based on sort of a sub Reddit thread. It’s like a grassroots cult legend,” he said of the new movie.

“It’s basically about a stranger that gets into our house and holds us captive while he teaches us how to be a ‘good family.’ Let’s just say that the lessons are not ones you would like to have taught to you.”
Figure skating champ Ilia Malinin on how he stays cool under pressure
At just 20 years old, Ilia Malinin has already made history. In 2022, the champion men’s figure skater became the first — and only — skater to ever land a quadruple axel in competition.
“I had many emotions going through my head. It was crazy, like, just landing it. I felt really relieved, and I was excited that it happened,” Malinin told TODAY.com on Monday.
“But I knew I had the rest of the performance to go. So, I was like, ‘OK, I landed it, I have to put it aside for now and keep going.’ But once the program ended, I was really happy for it.”
In 2024, he took home the men’s singles title at the World Figure Skating Championships and did it yet again in March of this year. Next stop? He’s eyeing the Winter Olympic Games in Milan.
Competing on the world stage is, of course, no easy feat. How does Malinin keep his stress in check?

“For me, music helps a lot,” he explained. “Just being able to listen to different types of music to either calm myself down or get myself into the right mood and the right mindset is what I use before my competitions.”
Jim Gaffigan reveals what bourbon and gardening have in common
Funnyman Jim Gaffigan stopped by Studio 1A and entertained the co-hosts during the 3rd hour of TODAY by telling Al Roker jokes and enjoying a few sips of his new bourbon, Fathertime, to boot.
Whiskey is the comedian’s latest passion, and during a conversation Monday with TODAY.com, Gaffigan explained why he decided to embark on the venture.

“The bourbon thing — that’s just for fun,” he said. “The great irony is that people are like, ‘Oh, you’re doing this to make money.’” But the truth is that he actually just loves American whiskey culture and finds the distilling process fascinating.
“Sometimes people on social media are like, ‘I can’t believe you’re lowering yourself to sell alcohol.’ And I’m like, ‘It’s even worse than that; I’m not doing it for the money,’” he laughed.
“It’s like gardening,” he said about his other great passion. “Anyone who gardens is losing money.”
Yet he loves it.
“Some of it’s luck, some of it’s hard work and some of it’s self-education,” Gaffigan explained.
Either way, both of his current hobbies offer the occasional reprieve from his full-time job parenting his five children, all of whom are between ages 12 and 21.
“It’s like living in a psych ward,” he joked with TODAY.com.
“The task and sacrifice of parents of most teenagers, it’s enormous,” Gaffigan said. He added that getting into the minds of teenagers can be tricky business.
“That’s why there’s bourbon,” he summed up.
Blake Shelton considers himself a ‘traditional’ country artist. But his new single ‘Texas’ is ‘different than anything’  he’s done before

Blake Shelton just dropped his 13th studio album, “For Recreational Use Only,” a project he told TODAY.com was four years in the making. On Tuesday, he hit the plaza for TODAY’s Citi Concert Series and later told us about how this album came together.

“I don’t really think of the album as, like, inspired by anything,” he said. “I’ve always kind of just approached making an album — just find the best songs I can possibly get my hands on, you know? I never set out with a direction.”
“That’s probably why my music’s been all over the map for my entire career,” he added, laughing.
When compiling the myriad of songs for an album, Shelton said he looks for “a great lyric” or “something that’s challenging as a vocalist.”
At the same time, Shelton noted that he aims to remain true to himself as an artist through the process.
“Who I am as a country artist, I think I lean more traditional, probably, but I’m always trying to find something new, push the boundaries a little bit,” he said.
Shelton joked that he’s “way behind when you listen to the radio,” but he’s still always searching for “what the next thing is.”
“I think ‘Texas’ is a good example of that, way different than anything I’ve done before,” he said of his new single.
Annie Murphy addresses possibility of future ‘Schitt’s Creek’ reboot
Annie Murphy, who won an Emmy Award for her role as Alexis on the beloved sitcom “Schitt’s Creek,” weighed in on fans never-ending question: Will there be a reboot?
“Listen, I want that as badly as other people seem to. I’m not going to stop trying to manifest that,” she told TODAY.com on Tuesday.
Whether another version of “Schitt’s Creek” ever comes to fruition, Murphy said much of the cast has reunions of their own.
“We all like try to keep in touch as much as we can,” Murphy said, acknowledging their “beyond busy” schedules. “Because it was such a special show for all of us. And we all love each other so much.”

Though the comedy, which ran for six seasons, wrapped five years ago, Murphy said she’s still stopped on the street for one of her character’s iconic lines. When Alexis would bicker with her brother (Dan Levy), she was known to memorably yell, “Ew, David!”
Murphy only actually said the line three times in the entire series, but her Valley Girl accent was so memorable that any “Schitt’s Creek” fan would recognize the phrase.
When fans do remember the line, Murphy said it’s sometimes “screamed in my face,” while others firmly command the actor, “‘Do it now.’” But, she told TODAY.com, she found a way out.

“Now I often just start going, like, ‘No, how about you do it? And I’m right here with you. I’m just your support animal, and you can go for it.’ And people tend to,” she said. “That’s like a way out. I’ve planted a little loop for myself.”
Now, Murphy stars in Season 2 of the Hulu drama “Nine Perfect Strangers” as Imogen, a character far different from Alexis. But would the two ever be friends?

“That is a very good question. No, I think Imogen would write Alexis off as a ditz — even though Alexis is not a ditz,” Murphy said. “But I think Imogen is a very judgy little minx, and I think she would make a pretty hard judgment and judge a book by its cover and never look back.”

title: Bravo’s Ashley Darby says her kids haven’t met anyone she’s dated. What it would take to change that
summary: "The Real Housewives of Potomac" and "Bravo's Love Hotel" star Ashley Darby talks dating and co-parenting with ex-husband Michael Darby in a TODAY.com interview.
story: While Ashley Darby is embracing her more vulnerable side on Bravo’s new reality dating series, back home, she’s a proud mom to her two sons.
“Bravo’s Love Hotel,” which is airing weekly now on the network, shows Ashley and three other single “Real Housewives” looking for love with potential male suitors in Los Cabos, Mexico.
Ashley said on the show she wanted to date more “age-appropriate” men, which is something she tells TODAY.com is “still a work in progress.”

“I would say that just men of different decades, whether it’s 20s, 30s or 40s — 50s or 60s, I would even say — they all just sort of present their own challenges,” she says. “So I’m trying to navigate all of it.”

The 36-year-old married Michael Darby, who’s currently in his 60s, in 2014. They welcomed two sons together: Dean in 2019 and Dylan in 2021. The ups and downs of their relationship played out on “The Real Housewives of Potomac” over the years, and Ashley confirmed they had separated in 2022 to Bravo’s “The Daily Dish.” The two finalized the divorce earlier this year, People reported.
She says co-parenting with her ex is “much better” now.
“I think that the finality of our divorce just sort of closed a lot of chapters for both of us,” Ashley says, adding they have a custody agreement and vacation schedule.
Now that things are “more clear and defined,” they “know how to operate,” she says.
Over the last three years, there’s one thing in particular Ashley has learned that she would share with other single moms.

“The biggest thing, where I really had to lean in, was asking for help,” she says. “When I was married, I was the caregiver, the homemaker. That was everything — I did the laundry, I cooked, I did the dishes. That was what I did. I loved it.”

Ashley says now she is adjusting to “the big undertaking” of having her own house while keeping up with her growing boys’ after-school activities. She explains she recently asked a neighbor to take one of her sons to a baseball game.
“It was uncomfortable for me to ask that, but she was so welcoming and so helpful,” Ashley says. “And I was like, ‘Man, what was I so uncomfortable about?’”
When it comes to introducing a partner to her kids since her split, Ashley says, “So far, my children have not met somebody who I am romantically dating.”
There was one instance, she says, in which someone she was getting to know was present at a social event she and her children were at.

“My children just associate that person just like anybody else,” she says. “It will take, probably, me loving somebody and actually saying the l-word for me to feel comfortable enough, because if I love them, then that means I feel sort of trust and confidence with them, that I’d trust them around my children. So we would really have to get to the love part, which is very hard for me, you know, as a divorcée.”

Even though Ashley, who is bisexual, is testing the waters with eligible men on “Bravo’s Love Hotel,” she says women have “100%, yes” been part of her dating experience since she and her ex-husband ended things.
She points out WorldPride, an event that supports the LGBTQ+ community, will take place in Washington, D.C., this year.

“D.C. was called, if not the gayest, one of the gayest cities in America,” Ashley says. “It’s very nice that I’ve met quite a few interesting ladies, attractive ladies, very intelligent ladies. So yeah, I’m keeping my options open.”
While her sons are young now, she says one day she “definitely will be open” with them about how to be and love as they are.
“I’m not stifling them or restricting them in any way they choose to express themselves,” Ashley says.
She explains one of her sons has a pair of boots with a “super high heel.”
“He calls them ‘moon boots,’” she says.

“I think in the past, with some of our archaic thinking, like, ‘Oh no, you can’t wear those!’” she adds. “But I’m just like, ‘Yeah, you want to club around in my shoes?’ You know? And have a good time.”

title: Benito Skinner plays his college self in 'Overcompensating' to tell a pop culture-filled coming out story
summary: Benito Skinner discusses what parts of "Overcompensating" are based on his own life and the significance of all those pop culture references and hit soundtrack.
story: Warning: This post contains spoilers for Season 1 of “Overcompensating.”
The opening scene of “Overcompensating” on Prime Video is similar to an experience its star, Benito Skinner, had during one of his first sleepover parties with friends — just a bit more absurd.
The scene shows a young Skinner rewinding a very specific portion  of the 1997 film “George of the Jungle,” starring Brendan Fraser, until one of his friends asks if they can do something else.
Skinner changes the channel and lands on the beginning of the music video for Britney Spears’ hit 2000 song, “Lucky.”

“I think all these moments were kind of pivotal in my journey,” Skinner tells TODAY.com. “Like, ‘Lucky’ was the song that I think changed my life in so many ways. As a kid, I was like, ‘Oh, I love Britney in a different way than everyone around me. I’m relating to this song in ways that no one else knows.’”

The pop culture references don’t stop coming in the first season of Skinner’s Prime Video series, which follows a first-year college student, Benny, as he tries to hide his sexuality from those around him and present as a straight man who loves football and girls.

Over the course of “Overcompensating's” eight episodes, Charli XCX performs three pre-“Brat” hits, Megan Fox is featured prominently on a poster in Benny’s dorm room, and cameos include Bowen Yang, Matt Rogers, Kaia Gerber and more. Skinner also brought in TikTok stars like Nadia Alexeev to dance during a frat party scene.
“That had to be done,” Skinner says. “Drunk girl dancing? Nadia.”
The premise of “Overcompensating” comes from Skinner’s own experiences, he says, but he felt he needed to amp up certain dramatic elements for the show.

“I feel like I really based it on feelings and experiences and relationships, so like the coming out things were as honest and true as we could go,” Skinner says. “Those feel like I did experience pretty much everything in the show.”
He adds that the relationship between his character Benny and his best friend, Carmen, played by Wally Baram, represents the friendships he’s had with women throughout his life.
“The relationship between Benny and Carmen is something that I felt with women my whole life, of them always being protectors for me,” Skinner says. “So that feels very real.”

Skinner, who rose to stardom through his comedy and celebrity impressions on social media, says that while certain aspects of the show are true to his real-life experiences, it was important to him and showrunner Scott King to fill the cast with people that will surprise viewers.

“Maybe you think you know them in the pilot, but you don’t,” Skinner explains. “At a certain point, your life starts to feel kind of like boring and not that interesting — like, you have to make a TV show, you need stakes.”
“So yeah, at a certain point, I was kind of like, ‘OK, I feel like my coming out story and these relationships are in there,'” he continues. “But now, let’s go.”
King tells TODAY.com that when writing the script with Skinner, they weren’t focusing on what situations would be the most dramatic or the most funny.
“We just wanted it to be real,” King says. “And even in the most heightened moments we wanted to play it real.”
King adds that while they were discussing their shared college experiences, he was surprised by how similar they were.

“As someone who graduated before Benny was even born, he and I, when we were talking about college, even though it was such different times, so different for gay men at those times, too, there was such a universality to our experiences,” King says. “And I think that’s where we were able to capture the comedy and the real.”
About those needle drops...
Music plays a central role in the show, Skinner says, with tracks coming in from Lorde, Lady Gaga and Nicki Minaj.
During a recent visit to Northwestern University, Skinner says he went to a sorority house, and some of the members asked about his show and its soundtrack.
“I said a few (songs) from the show, and they were like, ‘Totally,’” Skinner recalls. "And I was like, ‘Wait. Oh, so it’s like, a college bubble, like nothing has changed.’ I love that.”
Charli XCX notably plays herself in the show and serves as an executive producer on the series.

“I always knew that she had to be the college concert. Because when I was in college, I went to the ‘Sucker’ tour alone, because I didn’t want anyone to know, because that’s totally gay,” he says. “But I knew it had to be her.”
When working on Charli XCX's role in the script, Skinner says he wanted to give her more than just a performance.

“I don’t think we just wanted to slot her in — this is a comedy,” he says. “Like, we want people to die and be surprised and also, maybe if we can, weave in some kind of cathartic moment for musicians who are singing their life’s work to college kids who are on molly. Like, let’s do this.”

In the scene, Charli XCX performs three of her older hits, "Boom Clap," "Boys" and "I Love It," while Benny starts to feel ill from a hazing incident in which he had to swallow several live beta fish. His bestie Carmen was forced to eat extremely cheesy Italian food (even though she's lactose intolerant), and the pair try to make it through the concert. But they both end up in bathroom stalls next to each other getting extremely sick during her performance.
The juxtaposition of singing your life's work in front of hundreds of inebriated college students was a moment Charli XCX was plenty familiar with, Skinner says.

“When I sent it to her, she was like, 'I think I have said some of these things about playing "Boom Clap" at a college.' Like, ‘Why are you guys making me do this 100 times a year?’” he recalls Charli XCX saying.
“I mean it was such a no brainer that she was genius and was gonna kill it, so we had to give her as much as we could," Skinner adds. "And she did it in between ‘Sweat’ tour shows.”

Another music moment in "Overcompensating" that was inspired by Skinner's own life involves Lady Gaga’s song, “The Edge of Glory.” After having a strange experience at his school's secret society, Benny starts to have a panic attack and decides to go up to an openly gay student and ask him to hang out.
While Benny's talking with the student, the opening notes of "The Edge of Glory" begin to play, a nod to what the track feels like in Skinner's own life.
“Like leaving high school, rolling up the windows and blasting that and sobbing on the way home — like, that’s me,” Skinner says of his experience with the song.
“I think every song in it, it’s why we named the episodes after these songs," he adds. "I feel like, in college, music is currency.”
"Overcompensating" is now streaming on Prime Video.

title: Where are Jason Corbett’s kids from ‘A Deadly American Marriage’ now?
summary: Where are Jason Corbett's kids now? About Jack and Sarah's lives since the filming of A Deadly American Marriage.
story: The Netflix true crime documentary “A Deadly American Marriage” features extensive interviews with Jack and Sarah Corbett Lynch, the now-grown children of Jason Corbett.
Jason Corbett was killed in 2015 after being beaten with a baseball bat and a paving brick at his home in North Carolina.
His wife, Molly Martens, and her father, Tom Martens, were charged with second-degree murder, to which they both pleaded not guilty. This charge was later downgraded to voluntary manslaughter.

Corbett and Martens had been jointly raising Jack and Sarah Corbett Lynch, his son and daughter from his first marriage to Margaret Fitzpatrick, who died unexpectedly of an asthma attack in the early 2000s.

Following Corbett's death, the children were interviewed and medically assessed. At first, they both said they had witnessed their dad abusing Martens, according to a 2020 document from the Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
However, as shown in the documentary, they later recanted these claims and said they had been coached by Molly Martens to lie about their father’s behavior.
Keep reading to learn more about Jason Corbett’s kids and where they are now.
Who are Jason Corbett’s kids?
Sarah and Jack Corbett Lynch were born in Ireland to Jason Corbett and his first wife, Margaret “Mags” Fitzpatrick. They were very young when their mother died unexpectedly in the early 2000s.

Following his wife’s death, Jason Corbett hired Molly Martens to work as an au pair to care for the children. Romance eventually bloomed between Corbett and Martens, and the couple moved with the children to Davidson County, North Carolina in 2011. Molly Martens is from Tennessee.
Jack and Sarah Corbett Lynch were never formally adopted by Molly Martens, but they bonded with her from a young age and came to call her Mom, as seen in the documentary.
Following their father’s death, the children were taken back to Ireland to live with their aunt, Tracey Corbett Lynch, and her family.

As shown in the documentary, the children’s relationship with Molly Martens shifted in the aftermath of their father’s death. They began to speak out about their belief that she had not been acting in self-defense on the night of Corbett’s killing, but rather had murdered their father in cold blood.
In the documentary, Sarah Corbett Lynch shared her view that her father was the true “victim.”

Meanwhile, Molly Martens and her father, both interviewed in the documentary, tell a different story. She has maintained that her late husband was emotionally and physically abusive, and that she and her father were acting out of self-defense.

“I don’t know if a father can see something worse than watching his child die in front of him. I was going to save her life or die trying,” Tom Martens said in the documentary. “And I have no regrets.”
Molly Martens believes Jack and Sarah Corbett Lynch have been "weaponized against her." TODAY.com has reached out to Molly Martens for comment.
Where are Jack and Sarah Corbett Lynch now?
Both children appear to have added “Lynch” to their surnames, according to their social media profiles, in honor of the relatives who welcomed them into their family when they returned to Ireland.
In February, Sarah Corbett Lynch, now 18, released a memoir, “A Time for Truth: My Father Jason and My Search for Justice and Healing.”

“My book is about my life and my journey through the court system in America, and trying to find justice for my dad, and healing,” she said in a March Instagram video showing clips from her book launch in Limerick, Ireland.
She said writing the book has given her “a voice.”

“I think it’s really important for people to know that I‘ve gotten through my trauma and I’ve gotten through my experiences, but there’s other people out there who are still experiencing it, and that’s really important.”
In 2020, Sarah Corbett Lynch also published a children’s book called “Noodle Loses Dad,” which helps kids process loss and grief.
Sarah Corbett Lynch opened up about her memories of Molly Martens in a recent interview with Ireland’s Newstalk FM.
She alleged that her former stepmother’s behavior toward her and her brother was “not OK” for as long as she could remember.

“I was five years old and Molly started telling me that my dad killed my birth mom,” she said. "That’s not OK. It’s not true, but I didn’t know any different. She got into my head at a really young age, and we knew not to disobey her.”
She also alleged that Molly Martens grew upset when she saw Sarah Corbett Lynch had kept a photo of her birth mom in her room.
“She (Martens) picked it up and she started screaming at me saying, ‘This is not your mother.  ‘I’m your mother. This woman is dead.’ And she threw it down the stairs,” Corbett Lynch said.
Today, Sarah Corbett Lynch often posts photos on Instagram of herself with her aunt, Tracey Corbett Lynch, who she now refers to as her mother.
“Happy birthday to the wonderful woman who has always had my back and always made me feel loved. Thank you for being my mom,” Sarah Corbett Lynch wrote in one recent post.
Earlier in May, she also shared an Instagram tribute to her late birth mother.

“Today would have been my Mam’s 50th birthday. I’m celebrating her life by being as compassionate and kind as I can, surrounded by the same people who loved her and us unconditionally,” she wrote in the caption.

“I know you’re with us in spirit, Mam, with Dad holding your hand. I can feel that today you would be doing something meaningful right here with me, Jack, and everyone who is still here supporting us,” she also wrote.
Jack Corbett Lynch, now 20, does not share as much on social media, and his Instagram account is set to private.
He makes the occasional appearance on his sister’s page, and was seen supporting her in the video she shared of her book launch earlier this year.
Sarah Corbett Lynch also shared a selfie featuring her brother as she celebrated his birthday in 2022.
In the documentary, Jack Corbett Lynch opened up about his feelings about his dad.
“My dad was my hero,” he said. “He was someone I looked up to. He was my best friend.”
Are Jason Corbett’s kids still in touch with Molly Martens?
Neither of Jason Corbett’s kids appear to be on speaking terms with their former stepmother.
In the documentary, both Jack and Sarah Corbett Lynch talked about wanting to move on from their relationship with Martens.
“I don’t hate her, I just don’t want to give her any power over me anymore,” Jack Corbett Lynch said.
His sister also shared her belief that the charge of voluntary manslaughter, to which Martens pleaded no contest, was “a travesty of justice.”
“My dad deserves so much more from the justice system. I don’t have any feelings for the Martens now,” she said, referring to Molly Martens and her father, Tom Martens.

“They have taken so much from me and I’ve spent more than half of my life in the judicial system because of their actions," Sarah Corbett Lynch continued. "I’ve lost my dad, they tried to ruin his good name ... and I don’t want them to have any bit in my future.”
According to a sentencing document viewed by TODAY.com, Molly Martens is prohibited from contacting members of Jason Corbett's family.

title: EXCLUSIVE: Tammy Slaton can finally get skin removal surgery in new '1000-lb Sisters' clip
summary: Tammy Slaton reaches a much-anticipated milestone in her weight-loss journey in the upcoming episode of "1000-lb Sisters."
story: Tammy Slaton reaches a much-anticipated milestone in her weight-loss journey in the upcoming episode of "1000-lb Sisters."
In TODAY.com's exclusive clip of the moment, the reality star visits her doctor, Dr. Eric Smith, to find out if she's been approved for skin removal surgery.

Since 2020, the TLC series has been following the reality star and her sister, Amy Slaton, as they have worked to lose weight together. The show has chronicled the highs and lows of their journey, including surgeries and setbacks.
The clip begins with Slaton sitting in Smith's office as he reveals whether she can undergo surgery to remove her excess skin.
“You’ve shown me that you can focus on your nutrition, and because of that, I’m giving you the green light to go back to Pittsburgh and get you scheduled to have your skin removed,” he says.
Upon hearing the news, Slaton smiles, laughs joyfully and thanks her doctor.
Smith goes on to explain that he's already spoken with her surgeon, who is "on the same page as me."
"He’s comfortable proceeding with your skin removal surgery, so let’s get it done," he adds.
In a confessional interview, Slaton reflects on the exciting moment.
"'You’re approved.' What? You gave me all that big spiel about not having enough protein, but yet, you were going to let me go up there. OK, cool, thanks," she quips.
Back in the doctor's office, Smith asks Slaton how the news makes her feel.
"Relieved," she replies.
"Relieved? Good," he says. "I mean, Tammy, you’ve put the work in."
In his own confessional interview, Smith says he's "super excited" for his patient.

"I know this is something that she’s wanted for a really long time," he explains. "It’s not the end of her journey by any means. But it’s kind of that final thing of a reward that I’ve done all this hard work and now I can have this battle scar removed from me."
While talking with Slaton, Smith suggests that they play a joke on her brother, Chris Combs, who is sitting in the waiting room.
"Do you think they think you’re going to get the green light?" he asks.
"They don’t know," she replies.
"Can you fake cry?" he asks.
"I could try," she says.
"Maybe you scream at me," he teases.
In a confessional interview, Slaton reflects on Smith's suggestion, saying, "Not too many people know this about Dr. Smith, but he likes telling jokes and he’s a trickster."
The doctor then steps out into the waiting room and addresses Slaton's family, saying, "Hey, guys, take it easy on her. She's really upset. OK? She’s really bummed out. Just take it easy on her, OK?
"I wasn’t planning on saying nothing," Combs replies.
Slaton seems to have abandoned the joke because she then walks out with a smile on her face and says, "I got approved."
The reality star then teases her relatives and says, "Well, God dang. Where's the excitement?"
"I don’t know what the hell’s going on. Dr. Smith’s saying one thing, Tammy’s saying another, and neither one of them got a d--- poker face that I’d bank on," Combs says in a confessional interview.

Smith has been one of Slaton's biggest supporters throughout her weight-loss journey. Before the latest season of "1000-lb Sisters" premiered, he took to Instagram to congratulate the reality star on her 500-pound weight loss and shared a video to show her body transformation.

In recent months, Slaton has shared several of her weight loss tips on Instagram, explaining that she prioritized protein and hydration. She's also highlighted the importance of finding a community to support you.
“Weight loss isn’t just a physical battle. It’s a mental one, too," she said in one recent video. "Having the right support makes all the difference.”

title: Legendary wrestling announcer Jim Ross says he's been diagnosed with colon cancer
summary: Legendary pro wrestling commentator Jim Ross, who worked with WWE for decades and is now with AEW, has been diagnosed with colon cancer.
story: Legendary pro wrestling commentator Jim Ross has been diagnosed with colon cancer.
The 73-year-old WWE Hall of Famer, who has been with All Elite Wrestling since 2019, wrote in a post on X on May 15 that he will undergo surgery after being diagnosed with the illness.
"Diagnosed this week with colon cancer," he wrote. "Surgery being scheduled in the next week or two. I appreciate your concern and support."
All Elite Wrestling expressed its support of one of wrestling's iconic play-by-play announcers.

"All Elite Wrestling joins fans around the world in sending love and support to Jim Ross as he battles colon cancer," the promotion wrote on X. "J.R. is a valued member of the AEW family, and we stand beside him during his journey toward recovery."
Ross has been treated multiple times for cancer in the last four years.
He shared in October 2021 on X that he had been diagnosed with skin cancer and would undergo treatment. Ross then declared on X in December 2021 that he was cancer-free.
In February 2024, he wrote on X that he had undergone "cancer surgery" on his right hip.

Ross also has experienced multiple bouts of Bell's palsy over the years, according to WWE. The condition causes the muscles on one side of the face to weaken and appear to droop, according to the Mayo Clinic. The symptoms are usually short term.
The Oklahoma native was a fixture with WWE from 1993 to 2013 and was inducted into the WWE Hall of Fame in 2007.
He is perhaps best known for his 1998 call of the Undertaker tossing  Mick "Mankind" Foley off the top of a steel cage into a broadcast table at a WWE event.
"That killed him! As God as my witness he is broken in half!!" Ross shouted in the moment.

title: Beyoncé seemingly spots ‘very demure’ creator Jools LeBron in the crowd and responds perfectly
summary: The TikTok influencer behind the viral "very demure" trend just had a full circle moment at a Beyoncé concert.
story: The TikTok influencer behind the viral "very demure" trend just had a full circle moment at a Beyoncé concert.
Chicago-based TikTok creator Jools Lebron is credited with sparking a trend in August 2024 after posting a video of herself styling her hair and makeup for work in a "very demure, very mindful" way.
“See how I look very presentable? The way I came to the interview is the way I go to the job,” she says in the Aug. 5 TikTok. “I’m very modest, I’m very mindful.”

Nearly one year later, Lebron's viral phrase remains a cultural phenomenon regularly referenced in pop culture. The actor Ralph Fiennes recited it as a monologue on the New Year's Eve special with hosted by Anderson Cooper and Andy Cohen.
As it turns out, even Beyoncé is in on the joke.
While attending a Beyoncé concert this week, Lebron caught one special moment on camera. In the clip posted to TikTok, the singer attempts to hype up the crowd.
“Y’all are being very demure," she says.
In response, one fan up front can be heard screaming,  "No f------ way! No way!"
"And I believe you can be louder," Beyoncé continues.
The singer and her band then lead the crowd in a chant to build excitement.
"That's better," she says, satisfied with their cheering.
The camera then pans to several fans in the front row, including Lebron, who looks stunned.
After watching the clip, the influencer’s followers shared their reactions in the comments section.
"Omg she saw youuuuu," one wrote.
Another joked, "She Knowles youu."
“A queen recognizing a queen,” another noted.
"And they thought demure was over,” one wrote.
Lebron has another connection to Beyoncé'. In April, Beyoncé's mother Tina Knowles surprised Lebron with a call.
"I just have to tell you, Jools — you're in my book a little bit," Knowles said.
Knowles went on to tell Lebron her catchphrase provided some levity during a "very, very scary thing" — her breast cancer diagnosis.
"I was crying. I was like really scared and upset. All of my girls were there and they just had to figure out a way to make me laugh," she explained.

"So they pulled up your video. You were so wonderful saying demure. We just kept watching that video over and over. And as I was going in to what I had to deal with, they said, 'Remember, be mindful.' It brought a smile to my face and it was so inspiring for me."
Lebron was rendered speechless by Knowles' story. "It's the last thing I expected today," she said.
There's a good chance Beyoncé knew Lebron would be in the crowd at her "Cowboy Carter" stop, thanks to this conversation.
In the video, Knowles invited Lebron to attend her Chicago book tour stop May 16, the day after Beyoncé's May 15 Chicago show, which Lebron confirmed she would be attending.

title: What is the May 16 'Dateline' episode about?
summary: Is there a new episode of Dateline tonight? Here's how to watch the episode on May 16
story: After releasing new episodes on the Sean "Diddy" Combs trial and the 2022 Idaho murders, "Dateline" is airing re-run of Season 31's "Who Killed Mindy Morgenstern?" on May 16.
The episode centers around the mysterious 2006 murder of a 22-year-old North Dakota college student that left a small town searching for answers.
Read on to discover when and how to catch the episode and hints about what it will contain.
Is there a new episode of 'Dateline' tonight?
Catch a re-run of Season 31's "Who Killed Mindy Morgenstern?" on May 16. The episode initially aired on February 10, 2023.

Mindy Morgenstern's 2006 brutal murder shocked the small college town of Valley City, North Dakota.

The episode features interviews with multiple law enforcement officials, Morgenstern’s friends, her sister, Rebecca, and her parents, Eunice and Larry.
Watch the episode to see all the twists and turns the case took.

title: Tony Todd's last 'Final Destination' cameo is a poignant goodbye to his fans
summary: The directors and producer reflect on filming the late Tony Todd's poignant, last on-screen appearance in the new movie "Final Destination Bloodlines."
story: Warning: This article contains spoilers for “Final Destination Bloodlines.”

The most basic rule of any "Final Destination" movie is that, ultimately, no one survives — except for one character: The endlessly intriguing mortician William J. Bludworth, played by horror legend Tony Todd.
So when Todd, of "Candyman" fame, passed away last November at 69, it was only fitting that this death-obsessed series gave him a sendoff as intriguing and memorable as the character he played.

Todd's role as Bludworth in "Final Destination Bloodlines," released May 16, was one of his final on-screen appearances, filmed just months before he passed away, directors Adam Stein and Zach Lipovsky tell TODAY.com.

"What he developed with Bludworth is really special because it’s the only piece of the franchise that continues," Lipovsky says, adding that he brought a degree of "charm and mystery" to the role that was "delightful" and inspired countless fan theories.
The directors knew he was ill when they were crafting the story and with filming with him, Lipovsky explains.
"So we knew it was going to be his last 'Final Destination' movie and, potentially, his last film ever."
They took that responsibility seriously and worked with Todd to create a backstory for his character that would help answer some lingering questions.
But they also wanted to "give him an opportunity to say goodbye to the character, to the audience and all the people that love everything that he's been doing," Lipovsky says.
In the scene, Bludworth reveals that he's sick and knows his own time is limited. There are ways to cheat death, he tells the characters, but things are likely to get "messy."

Sooner or later, he says, death is coming for all of us. "I intend to enjoy the time I have left," he tells them, "and I suggest you do the same." He continues, "Life is precious. Enjoy every single second. You never know when."

The fact that Todd knew he was likely facing his final months in real life "gave that scene real authenticity," says longtime “Final Destination” producer Craig Perry, adding that it "translated into one of the most poignant moments in the entire franchise."

And Todd's contribution to the series was "enormous," Perry tells TODAY.com. When initially casting the for the role, which first appeared in the original "Final Destination" in 2000, "we wanted somebody who always looked like he had a secret that he wasn't telling, a sort of enigma behind his eyes," Perry says.
In Todd, they found all that and more.

"We really felt that Tony had all of that gravitas and mystery in his very DNA," Perry says. "His presence brought a sense of foreboding medicine mystery, and beyond that, he was able to have a playfulness that made the character fun to watch."

Todd elevated basic exposition — and transcended typical "magical Negro" horror tropes. In fact, Stein says, part of their direction with the character was “wanting to kind of explode that trope and show that, no, Bludworth was a real person.”

In the previous movies, Bludworth has been a "mysterious mentor figure, so (Todd) was very excited to show how he knows so much about death — as a real person," Stein explains. "It's not because he's an angel or death itself," he continues, "it's because he had this experience in his life."
Taking the idea even further, Bludworth tells this latest crop of young people trying to deceive death that they aren't the first who have come to him for advice — and he's done with all that.
"That was to comment on even how cinema has changed a bit," Stein says. "Like, we're not doing that anymore."

While filming, Todd was "just so incredibly joyful," Stein recalls. He was physically weak, but "so excited," he says. Todd especially wanted to take photos with the actors who play Bludworth's mother and child self, Stein says, as his characters in other films often didn't get such fleshed-out backstories.

And when it came time to perform his final speech, the directors told him to "throw the script away for a moment and just speak from the heart," Lipovsky says. "It was a unique opportunity for him to speak in character to what's happening in the story, but on a secondary level, be speaking to the audience about himself."
The take in the film is the one Todd improvised.

"Even the way that he says 'Good luck' and winks at the camera as he walks out and starts whistling is sort of his own gift of talking about heavy things, but with a dark and delightful charm," Lipovsky says. "The whole cast and crew couldn't believe that he had given us that."

title: Did Blake Lively threaten Taylor Swift? What Justin Baldoni's lawyer is alleging in new docs
summary: Justin Baldoni’s lawyer is alleging that Blake Lively's lawyer “demanded” Taylor Swift release a statement supporting her in the latest development involving the legal battle between the two “It Ends With Us” stars.
story: A day after Justin Baldoni's lawyer, Bryan Freedman, alleged that Blake Lively “demanded” Taylor Swift release a statement supporting her, Judge Lewis J. Liman has had the accusations stricken from the case.

On Thursday, May 15, Judge Liman — who is presiding over the trial between the two “It Ends With Us” stars set for March 9, 2026, in New York — described Freedman's letter as "improper" and said it "must be stricken," in a court ruling obtained by TODAY.com.
"It is irrelevant to any issue before this Court and does not request any action from this Court," Judge Liman wrote.

He continued, "The sole purpose of the Letter is to 'promote public scandal' by advancing inflammatory accusations, on information and belief, against Lively and her counsel. It transparently invites a press uproar by suggesting that Lively and her counsel attempted to 'extort' a well-known celebrity."
At the end of Judge Liman's statement, he added, "Counsel is advised that future misuse of the Court’s docket may be met with sanctions."
Lively's spokesperson sent a statement to TODAY.com reacting to Judge Liman granting the request of the Lively's legal team to remove Freedman's allegations from the record.

“It took the court less than 24 hours to see through Mr. Freedman’s irrelevant, improper and inflammatory accusations, strike them, remove them from the court and warn Mr. Freedman that further misconduct may be met with sanctions,” Lively's spokesperson said in a statement.
TODAY.com has reached out to Freedman for a comment.

Liman's decision regarding Freedman's accusations is the latest development involving the legal battle between the two former co-stars. Following Swift’s spokesperson addressing the pop star reportedly being subpoenaed in Lively and Baldoni’s legal back-and-forth, Freedman filed a letter with Judge Liman on May 14, in which the attorney wrote that the purpose of the subpoena was to access discovery regarding “witness tampering and evidence spoliation.”

He said that the counsel for Wayfarer Parties, which includes Baldoni, received “information from a source who is highly likely to have reliable information” alleging that Lively asked Swift to delete their text messages. Freedman then claimed that Michael Gottlieb, Lively’s lawyer, contacted Swift’s attorney and “demanded that Ms. Swift release a statement of support for Ms. Lively, intimating that, if Ms. Swift refused to do so, private text messages of a personal nature in Ms. Lively’s possession would be released.”

Freedman further described the alleged demands as “inappropriate and apparently extortionate threats” and said a representative for Swift responded to them in “at least one written communication” sent to Gottlieb.

“It is those communications that the Wayfarer Parties seek to obtain by way of subpoena, as they would evidence an attempt to intimidate and coerce a percipient witness in this litigation,” Baldoni’s lawyer continued.
TODAY.com obtained a statement from Gottlieb regarding Freedman’s letter to the judge, in which he called the accusations “categorically false.”

“It should be unnecessary to respond to anonymously sourced, baseless, allegations recklessly leveled without any supporting evidence. It is worth stating for the record, however, that each of the allegations in the Freedman Letter is unequivocally and demonstrably false. As a legal matter, the Freedman Letter is improper. It does not seek any form of relief, is irrelevant to any motion currently pending before the Court, and serves no legitimate purpose. It is not useful to the Court in any respect,” Lively's lawyers wrote.
They also said that Freedman’s letter appeared intended to “launder scandalous and defamatory allegations about Ms. Lively and opposing counsel into the press.”
TODAY.com reached out to Swift’s rep for a comment, as well.

Swift’s spokesperson previously issued a statement regarding the subpoena, asserting that the musician has no connection to the movie adaptation besides her song “My Tears Ricochet” being featured on the soundtrack. Her rep said that the witness summons was a way to generate “tabloid clickbait.”

“Taylor Swift never set foot on the set of this movie, she was not involved in any casting or creative decisions, she did not score the film, she never saw an edit or made any notes on the film, she did not even see ‘It Ends With Us’ until weeks after its public release, and was traveling around the globe during 2023 and 2024 headlining the biggest tour in history,” the statement said.

Her rep continued, “The connection Taylor had to this film was permitting the use of one song, ‘My Tears Ricochet.’ Given that her involvement was licensing a song for the film, which 19 other artists also did, this document subpoena is designed to use Taylor Swift’s name to draw public interest by creating tabloid clickbait instead of focusing on the facts of the case.”

Lively and Baldoni’s legal case began on Dec. 20 when Lively filed an 80-page sexual harassment complaint alleging that Baldoni created a hostile workplace environment on the set of “It Ends With Us” and that he later launched a smear campaign to “destroy” her reputation. She also alleged that he crossed the line while they filmed intimate scenes and that he harassed her on set.
Freedman reacted to the accusations in a statement to TODAY.com at the time, calling them “completely false, outrageous and intentionally salacious.”

Lively then filed a federal lawsuit against Baldoni, his production company, Wayfarer Studios, producer Jamey Heath, crisis communications representative Melissa Nathan and publicist Jennifer Abel on Dec. 31. Her attorney alleged there was a “retaliatory campaign Wayfarer launched against her for reporting sexual harassment and workplace safety concerns.”

Following an article about Lively’s accusations, Baldoni sued The New York Times for libel. He also filed a lawsuit against Lively, her husband, Ryan Reynolds, Lively’s rep Leslie Sloane and Sloane’s PR firm on Jan. 16, accusing them of defamation and disregarding contractual claims.

Swift became linked to the case when Baldoni filed his suit, which included alleged text messages exchanged between him and Lively. In the documents, a “Taylor” is referenced and described as a “megacelebrity friend.”
Baldoni’s team confirmed to NBC News at the time that the “Taylor” in the suit was the pop singer, who has been friends with Lively for years.

According to NBC News, one alleged text from Lively read, “If you ever get around to watching Game of Thrones, you’ll appreciate that I’m Khaleesi, and like her, I happen to have a few dragons. For better or worse, but usually better. Because my dragons also protect those I fight for. So really we all benefit from those gorgeous monsters of mine. You will too, I can promise you.”

title: Michael J. Fox returning to TV with a guest spot on this popular show
summary: Michael J. Fox will guest star in the third season of the Apple TV+ series "Shrinking," which stars Harrison Ford and Jason Segel.
story: Michael J. Fox is returning to his roots.
The five-time Emmy Award winner will guest star in the third season of the Apple TV+ series “Shrinking.”
The streaming service and the actor shared a collaborative Instagram post with the news May 15.
“Big feelings incoming. Michael J. Fox joins the Shrinking cast as a guest star in season 3,” the caption reads. “Shrinking Season 2 — Now Streaming.”
There are no details on what role Fox will play.

In “Shrinking,” Harrison Ford plays a therapist who, it’s disclosed at the end of the first season, has Parkinson’s disease, the same disease Fox revealed in 1998 he had. Fox recently partnered with Apple TV+ on the 2023 Emmy-winning documentary “Still,” which chronicled his life and history with Parkinson’s.

Fox will reteam on “Shrinking” with co-creator and executive producer Bill Lawrence, who co-created the sitcom “Spin City,” which Fox starred in before leaving the series and retiring from full-time acting in 2000 to instead focus on his foundation. Fox won his fourth Emmy Award for “Spin City” after he won three for “Family Ties.”

Fox made many more appearances on the small screen over the years, even winning another Emmy for his guest role on the FX series “Rescue Me” in 2009. He would earn another five Emmy nominations for his work on the CBS drama “The Good Wife.” Fox also appeared on “Designated Survivor,” “Curb Your Enthusiasm” and “Boston Legal,” and he starred in his own short-lived series, “The Michael J. Fox Show.”
“Shrinking” will be Fox’s first on-screen TV acting role since he appeared on “The Good Wife” spinoff, “The Good Fight,” in 2020.
That same year, Fox revealed he planned to retire from acting for a second time.
“The nascent diminishment in my ability to download words and repeat them verbatim is just the latest ripple in the pond,” he wrote in his memoir “No Time Like the Future.”

“There are reasons for my lapses in memorization — be they age, cognitive issues with the disease, distraction from the constant sensations of Parkinson’s, or lack of sensation because of the spine — but I read it as a message, an indicator,” he wrote.
“There is a time for everything, and my time of putting in a twelve-hour workday, and memorizing seven pages of dialogue, is best behind me,” he continued. “At least for now.”
Fox also poked some fun at the challenges acting presented to him, although he didn’t necessarily close the door on returning to his trade.
“In fairness to myself and to producers, directors, editors, and poor beleaguered script supervisors, not to mention actors who enjoy a little pace, I enter a second retirement,” he wrote.
“That could change, because everything changes. But if this is the end of my acting career, so be it.”

title: Are ‘Secret Lives of Mormon Wives’ stars Jen and Zac Affleck still together now? Season 2 gives an update
summary: Are Secret Lives of Mormon Wives stars Zac and Jen Affleck still together now? Here's an update for Season 2.
story: Filming “The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives” forced Jen and Zac Affleck to face some difficult truths in their marriage.

After a bombshell fight in Season 1 left viewers wondering if the couple was headed for a divorce, the Afflecks are back for Season 2 of the Hulu reality series and they’re ready to give an update on where their marriage stands.
But first, the couple has to confront their differences and work to mend their fractured relationship.

Whether you’ve already binge watched Season 2 or you’re looking to catch up before tuning in, we’re taking a look back on the fight that shook up the Afflecks’ marriage and breaking down the current status of their marriage.
What happened between Jen and Zac Affleck in Season 1?

Hulu viewers were introduced to the Afflecks in Season 1 of “The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives.” Jen Affleck met her future husband on a Mormon dating app when she was 18 years old. After getting married in 2019, they had their first child, a daughter named Nora, in 2021. A son named Luca arrived in 2023.
Jen and Zac Affleck’s Mormon values created some challenges for the couple in Season 1 of “The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives.”

When the #MomTok ladies ended up at a Chippendales show in Las Vegas, Jen Affleck was worried that attending the show would be “disrespectful” to her husband. When she told Zac Affleck she was at the show, they got into a big fight.
Later on, Jen Affleck told her co-stars her husband said he “didn’t want to be married to her” if she “does stuff like this.”
In an interview with TODAY.com before Season 1 premiered, Jen Affleck said she thought her husband was mad because of “the context of the situation.”

“If we were at a bachelorette party and we’re just celebrating, it wouldn’t have been a big deal. But because we’re representing our church, and (I think) he knew that millions of people were going to see that, (he was) scared that they would put me in a tough situation with filming, and that they would portray me in a different light that I’m not,” she said.
What happened between Zac and Jen Affleck after Season 1 premiered?
Shortly after “The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives“ premiered, Jen took to TikTok to acknowledge that appearing on the show was difficult.
“Lets just say this 1st season was rough for us,” she captioned a video of herself and her husband.

After Season 1 premiered, Jen Affleck told Decider the Chippendales fight “strengthened” her marriage. The #MomTok influencer also told Vulture that she and her husband had been doing “therapy nonstop” since filming the first season.

“If we continue in our relationship, there are changes that need to be made. If they’re not made, we might have to… look at other options. But as of right now, I do think he’s trying his best to make those changes,” she said.

On Sept. 19, Jen Affleck posted a tribute to her husband and a recap of the state of their marriage on Instagram. The lengthy caption was accompanied by photos. She credited her husband's support for her own success.

“I couldn’t have done it without Zac. Is Zac perfect? No. Does he have flaws that we’ve needed to address. Yes. But I can confidently say he’s always supported and believed in me more than anyone else,” she said.
She confirmed that they are still together amid the “struggles like so many marriages have.”

“But do we love each other? Yes. Are we willing to put in the work to be better? Yes. Have there been moments when we wanted to walk away? Of course. But there’s so much more to our marriage and what we offer to each other than people realize,” she said.
What happened between Zac and Jen Affleck in Season 2?
Early on in Season 2, viewers learned that Jen and Zac Affleck were spending some time apart after their big Chippendales blowout.
“It’s been a few months of straight hell since Vegas,” Jen Affleck revealed, adding that she was “separated” from her husband.

A few months beforehand, the couple was committed to moving to New York so Zac Affleck could attend medical school. However, he later got accepted to a school in Arizona and the family moved there. Amid their marital issues, Jen Affleck returned to Utah and #MomTok.

When Zac Affleck visited his wife in the season premiere, he expressed his desire to move back in with her and put his medical school education on hold. Still, Jen Affleck seemed hesitant since their relationship had been so “rocky” recently.

In a confessional interview, she outlined what she needed from her husband in order to mend their relationship, saying, “For me to want to fight for our marriage, I need to feel like he’s putting my feelings before his.”
Zac Affleck then pleaded his case, saying he “messed up” and was working on himself while attending therapy.
“I want to prove to you that I love you and that I am a good husband and I am a good father. I want to fight for our marriage and that’s why I’m here,” he said.
Jen Affleck told her husband they needed to be “equals” for their marriage to work moving forward.
In a confessional interview, Zac Affleck admitted that the world’s response to their Chippendales fight had taken its toll on their relationship.
“After Vegas it felt like the whole world was against us and wanted us to get a divorce. I had so many regrets about how I acted and the way that things went down,” he said.

Although she was still adamant that separation was best to help “figure out what’s best for our relationship,” Jen Affleck allowed her husband to move back in. However, she made him promise not to talk over her.
In addition to doing couples’ therapy, the couple experimented with ketamine therapy in an attempt to deepen their emotional connection.

Zac Affleck hasn’t always been the best of friends with his wife’s #MomTok pals. The brewing tension, particularly with Demi Engemann and Jessi Ngatikaura, came to a head in Season 2 of the Hulu reality series.
After Jen Affleck said it was important that her husband be on good terms with her friends, Zac Affleck met up with the two TikTok influencers in one scene and attempted to clear the air.

The trio quickly realized that they may have received mixed signals from Jen Affleck. For instance, Engemann and Ngatikaura said Jen Affleck told them that Zac Affleck had gambled away his medical school tuition. Zac Affleck denied doing so.
Zac Affleck clapped back by saying Engemann and Ngatikaura weren’t there for his wife following the Chippendales fight. However, they felt differently.
The Afflecks later met up with Engemann and Ngatikaura and tensions rose. In a confessional interview, Engemann said she wasn’t sure who to believe.
“For so long, I was team Jen against Zac and now Jen’s showing erratic behavior and starting to lie and showing what kind of friend she is,” she said.
Meanwhile Jen Affleck questioned her bond with Engemann and Ngatikaura.
“After talking to Jessi and Demi, I don’t know where my friendship stands with them and if I can trust them,” she said in a confessional interview.
During a Halloween party, a few of the #MomTok ladies planned to have some of their husbands do a Chippendales dance for Jen Affleck. Zac Affleck watched on and looked uncomfortable.

“I don’t know whether to have a good time right now because I know that this is making Zac uncomfortable and because of how both Demi and Jessi treated my relationship prior to this. It makes me question their intentions,” Jen Affleck said in a confessional interview.
Meanwhile, Zac Affleck described the move as “another jab from Jessi and Demi” at his and his wife’s expense.

“I don’t know in what world they think that they have some right to give us exposure therapy. To force something onto someone, and especially not tell them, I don’t think that you can claim to have a good intention,” he said.
In a confessional interview, Jen Affleck later admitted that she knew her friends were planning the dance.

“I didn’t realize how bad this would upset Zac. I just wanted to be the fun friend who just said, 'Yeah, and that it would be so awesome.' But I didn’t really question their intentions behind it and I also didn’t ask myself how I felt about it,” she said in a confessional interview.
The #MomTok star also said her husband was “upset” and “jumping to conclusions” after the party. She called the experience “triggering.”
While talking with his wife, Zac Affleck explained his feelings.

“I am frustrated because I feel like I’m having to stick up and defend our family and it’s making me look like the bad guy when these are your friends,” he said. “If my friends were doing these kinds of things to us, I would confront them or I would drop them.”
During the discussion, Zac Affleck requested that the film crew stop filming and walked away, explaining that he wanted to have the conversation later.
Where does the couple stand today?
Jen and Zac Affleck are still together as of May 2025.

The couple announced that they were expecting their third child in February 2025. In an interview with People, the expectant mother said filming the reality series “took a toll” on her marriage and mental health.
“There were many dark days. There’s so much more to our story than people realize,” she said.
In a separate interview with People, Jen Affleck opened up about the work she and her husband had done on their marriage.
“Just because of everything that we went through last year and because of everything we’ve had to do so much therapy,” she said.
After returning to #MomTok, Jen Affleck acknowledged that the experience was “daunting” because she and her husband “have gone through so much being a part of it.”
The expectant mother said her husband still has a few months to decide if he’s going back to medical school. For now, “his priority is just supporting me.”

title: Oliver Stark unpacks Buck’s possible big life changes in the ‘9-1-1’ Season 8 finale
summary: Oliver Stark unpacks the ending of "9-1-1" Season 8, including if Buck is moving or leaving the 118.
story: 🚨🚨🚨Warning: This article contains spoilers from the "9-1-1" Season Eight finale, "Seismic Shifts."🚨🚨🚨
In typical "9-1-1" fashion, Season Eight ended with a bang — well, several.
After starting the season with a bee-nado (a tornado composed of bees, for anyone wondering), the Season Eight finale saw the 118 race to a more familiar scene: an infrastructure collapse.

The 118, still reeling without its captain, splits off in pairs at the scene of the high-rise building collapse, with Henrietta "Hen" Wilson (Aisha Hinds) and Howard “Chimney” Han (Kenneth Choi) rescuing several tenants, as Evan “Buck” Buckley (Oliver Stark) and Ravi Panikkar (Anirudh Pisharody) go to what's left of the upper levels.

LAPD Sgt. Athena Grant (Angela Bassett) was on scene when the apartment complex started crumbling down. She rushes back in to help, finding two pinned tenants in the building's laundry room. As their conditions worsen, she sends a survivor to get help, and Chimney joins her.

But with the team still inside, the unsteady building continues to shake, rocked with mini-explosions, leaving Buck and Ravi trapped with a victim and Chimney and Athena's exit route completely blocked.
For Buck, it marks a very different circumstance than one of the team's last big emergencies. In Episode 14, all of the 118 were locked inside a lab — except for Buck.
"I think he's almost more comfortable being trapped as long as he's able to do his job," Oliver Stark tells TODAY.com of the finale. "Being on the outside was the most jarring thing for him."

The lab disaster notably ended with the shocking death of Capt. Bobby Nash (Peter Krause). Quarantined in the lab, members of the 118 were exposed to a deadly virus. Chimney was infected, and he was saved via Athena and Buck’s heroics to acquire an antidote. But Bobby — Athena’s husband — was also infected and died in the lab.
In the finale — back to true "9-1-1" fashion — the 118 and Athena save the day, with no further casualties.
Here's how it all goes down (literally) — and, as Stark says, how the circumstances are hopefully introducing a more "mature" Buck looking ahead to the show's already-renewed Season Nine.
How does '9-1-1' Season 8 end?

The 118 has since seemingly fallen apart in the aftermath of Bobby's death. While they showed a united front at Bobby's funeral in Episode 16 — with Eddie Diaz (Ryan Guzman) returning from El Paso, Texas, after moving earlier in the season to be with his son — they are each grieving separately in the most recent episodes.

Chimney and Athena, both struggling with Bobby's sacrifice, can barely stand to be in the same room. Meanwhile, Buck and Eddie have another fight, with Eddie accusing Buck of being selfish about Eddie's new job opportunity in El Paso amid his grief.

For the 118, Episode 18 opens on a somber note. All gathered at the station, the team throws a going away lunch for Eddie, who's set to report for duty at an El Paso firehouse the next morning. He's given his turnout uniform, and he and Chris enjoy one last shared meal with the team. Hen says she's turned down taking the job of captain, while Buck reveals he's put in for a transfer.
"Out of the 118?" Eddie asks.
"It's just a number now," Buck responds.
The team then heads to the call at the building collapse. Stark says being in the thick of the action is Buck at his best.

"There are different sides of Buck, and some of them are a bit sillier. I don't know, he's just like guileless and golden retriever-y, but there is no doubt that he's an extremely adept firefighter," Stark says. "So I think him being in the emergency is where he's going to thrive and be able to do his best. I think it's a chance as well to see this more mature, calmer, 'let's get to work' version of Buck."

While the rest of team rescues victims, Eddie is packing up his gear and preparing to head to the airport with Chris to go back to Texas. Eddie then sees reports of the building collapse and the search-and-rescue response on the news. Donning his familiar uniform, he heads toward the rubble, just in time to save Buck, Ravi and one of the victims before the building collapses further.
"I was watching the news, had a bit of FOMO," Eddie tells Buck over the radio, before shooting a line gun to their location, allowing the trio to escape.
Stark says for Buck, that moment of Eddie coming to save the day represents a return to the status quo.

"I think just a case of things getting back to the way they're meant to be, and as we touched on, maybe never being quite the same, but the steps to repair slowly being built," Stark tells TODAY.com of Eddie's save.
The team, Eddie included, then head to rescue Athena, Chimney and their patients. In the end, everyone makes it back alive, with zero civilian casualties from the building collapse.

After the emergency and back at the station, Chimney notices the team rapidly splitting off despite their success as a united front. Eddie checks his phone looking for a flight back to El Paso while Buck puts away his turnouts. An emboldened Chimney orders everyone to stop moving and tells Eddie he's not leaving L.A. and Buck that he's not transferring.

"This is our fire house. This is the 118, and it's not just a number. It's us," an emotional Chimney tells the team. "... Cap is gone. But leaving won't change that. It won't make you feel any less sad. It just means that you'll be sad all alone."
He rounds out his speech with strict orders for everyone — Buck and Eddie included — to get some rest before reporting for their next shift "right here, together."
A shocked Hen responds, "Copy that, Cap — I mean, Chim," suggesting the 118 might not have to look far in Season Nine for its next leader.
Asked what stops Buck from considering leaving the 118, Stark tells TODAY.com, "It's not really his decision."
"It's very much told to him," Stark says. "'Put your stuff down. Get to work. This is where we live.' And it's what I think everybody needs to hear."
Eddie being ordered to stay brings in the literal question of living situations.
In Episode Nine, Buck moved into Eddie's house as a subletter so Eddie could follow Chris to El Paso. Since Eddie's return to L.A. for the funeral, he's been staying on Buck's couch in his old house.

In regards to their dynamic as roommates, Stark jokes, "Apparently they work out who's going to do the groceries and then they don't always follow through on that." (In Episode 17, Buck and Eddie's fight occurred in the kitchen and started after Buck picked up the groceries though Eddie said he would.)

"They work a lot of hours. That's the one thing as well. I don't think they spend a lot of time at home," he adds of Buck and Eddie's time as roommates. "So yeah, that is for the audience to fill in the blank for themselves."

In the final minutes of Episode 18, it's revealed that Eddie and Chris have moved back, Buck is looking for a new apartment and Athena is putting the now-finished house she had been building with Bobby on the market.
After he's asked by his realtor why he's leaving his last place, Buck says, "It wasn't really mine. I was subletting."

"Buck is looking for his own place again, and I just think that he's ready to — kind of the combination of everything's that's been happening through the season — the old apartment, the loft, is gone. This is Eddie's place. Who am I going to be, stand on my own two feet?" Stark says of what Buck is looking for.

A move may prove disheartening to longtime supporters of a potential romance between Buck and Eddie. Earlier in Season Eight, the show introduced the possibility onscreen for the first time after Buck reconnects with his ex, who insinuates he'd be open to getting back together "now that the competition's (Eddie) is out of the way." Buck was later point blank asked by sister Maddie (Jennifer Love Hewitt) is he was in love with Eddie, which he adamantly denied.
"You know when something huge happens, your personal dramas, they just, everything falls by the wayside a little bit," Stark says. "I don't know if that will be addressed next year or what."
Asked if Buck continued to think about that question before Bobby's death, Stark says he thinks Buck "shut it down."

"I don't think the idea is that Buck went home and looked in the mirror and said, 'Wait, am I in love with Eddie?' I think it came so far out of left field for him when Tommy first said it," Stark says. "I don't think the idea is that we were saying Buck now is questioning if that's true."

"And, you know, look, (showrunner) Tim (Minear) will make that decision if it is or not," he adds. "But I don't think in that moment that the story was now Buck is wondering if he is. I think Buck thought, 'No, you're absolutely wrong. What are you talking about?' And yeah, we'll go from there."
Overall, Stark says he hopes Bobby's death in Season Eight will give him a chance to play a more "mature Buck" going forward.

"I was excited that maybe this could be the thing that helps Buck mature or grow into a different place at a different stage," he says. "So I think that’s, from my point of view, anyway, what the fallout or the repercussions for Buck will be."

title: Who is Ryan Kiera Armstrong? New ‘Buffy’ star tearfully accepts reboot role from Sarah Michelle Gellar
summary: Ryan Kiera Armstrong has staked the role of the new slayer in town in the upcoming "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" revival.
story: Ryan Kiera Armstrong has staked the role of the new slayer in town in the upcoming "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" revival.
The 15-year-old actor will co-star with original series lead Sarah Michelle Gellar.
The two actors shared the news May 15 in a joint Instagram post featuring a video that showed Gellar breaking the casting news to Armstrong.
"How do you feel about helping me save the world?" 48-year-old Gellar asked Armstrong in the clip.
"Good," responded Armstrong, who appeared unsure of Gellar's meaning.
"Do you want to be my Chosen One"?" Gellar asked her, which prompted Armstrong to cover her mouth as she burst into tears.
"Will you stand by my side and save the world with me?" Gellar asked while Armstrong, sobbing still, nodded her head.
